description:

Al Jazeera's Gabriel Elizondo reports from the United Nations headquarters in New York.

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
Tension is rising across Gaza once again after Palestinian health officials say 25 people were killed and dozens more wounded in a series of Israeli airstrikes. The attacks hit the Shejaia and Zeitoun districts of Gaza City, as well as the Mawasi area west of Khan Younis. The Israeli military says it struck Hamas targets after its troops came under fire, an incident it calls a violation of the nearly six-week-old ceasefire. But all the casualties appear to be civilian.

Al Jazeera’s Zein Basravi reports.

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
The last time Marta saw her 14-year-old son was three months ago – he was wearing rebel army fatigues and holding a rifle as he marched down the street with the other child soldiers.

She ran to the commanding officer and begged him to release her boy, who had been abducted nine months earlier in the middle of the night from their home in eastern Colombia at age 13. The officer, part of a dissident group of the now-demobilised Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC, waved her away, threatening to shoot her if she didn’t leave.

Al Jazeera’s Teresa Bo reports from Cauca, Colombia.

description:
China is the world’s largest emitter of greenhouse gases, accounting for about 30 percent of global emissions.
President Xi Jinping has pledged to reduce the country's greenhouse gas emissions by 7-10% over the next 10 years. But many climate scientists say the target doesn’t go far enough.

Al Jazeera’s Katrina Yu reports from Huailai County in Hebei province, China.

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
The World Food Programme is warning 318 million people face critical levels of hunger next year.
The United Nations body says that is double the number compared to 2019. 
What is behind this worsening crisis that is putting so many people in danger? 

Presenter: Adrian Finighan

Guests: 

Jean-Martin Bauer - Director of Food Security and Nutrition Analysis Service at the United Nations World Food Programme.

Shahin Ashraf - Head of Global Advocacy at Islamic Relief Worldwide.

Manenji Mangundum - Oxfam's Country Director in Democratic Republic of Congo.

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) is operating in an unprecedented way during US President Donald Trump’s second term. The agency has existed for over 20 years, but now operates as a masked force. Imposters posing as agents have committed crimes such as kidnapping and sexual assault. The FBI has urged ICE officers to unmask and identify themselves. How did the agency get here?

In this episode:

- Hannah Allam, reporter, ProPublica

Episode credits:

This episode was produced by Haleema Shah, Sarí el-Khalili, and Diana Ferrero, with Melanie Marich, Farhan Rafid, Fatima Shafiq, Tamara Khandaker, and our guest host, Natasha del Toro. It was edited by Noor Wazwaz and Kylene Kiang.

Our sound designer is Alex Roldan.  Our video editors are Hisham Abu Salah and Mohannad al-Melhem. Alexandra Locke is The Take’s executive producer. Ney Alvarez is Al Jazeera’s head of audio.
title: Is ICE in the US operating as secret police? | The Take

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
In the turquoise waters surrounding the Tongan islands of Vava’u, a man who goes by George spends his days guiding visitors into the realm of whales.
George & The Whales is a cinematic portrait of a whale-watching guide whose life is intertwined with the humpback whales that return to Tonga’s warm Pacific waters each summer to breed and nurse their young.
Through George’s quiet reflections and breathtaking underwater imagery, this documentary short captures a rare sense of peace and understanding between humans and nature.

A film by Nessim Stevenson, produced by What Took You So Long? production.

description:
US President Donald Trump says the so-called “Gaza board of peace” will include representatives from several countries.
The board will serve as an interim administration, handling security, public services and reconstruction. 
It's part of a resolution passed by the UN Security Council, based on a US-drafted plan but it's unclear how it will be implemented.
Palestinians say they are more concerned about the daily challenges they are facing.

Al Jazeera’s Ibrahim al-Khalili reports from Gaza City, Palestine.

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
Al Jazeera’s journalists risk everything to report on Israel’s war on Gaza, enduring adversity, displacement, and the deaths of their colleagues and families.

The concluding episode chronicles the war’s final months before a ceasefire begins in October. Al Jazeera’s journalists continue their coverage despite the destruction caused by the relentless Israeli bombing, mounting casualties and intolerable working conditions across Gaza. Israel’s targeting of journalists becomes ever clearer as the violence claims more lives, including highly respected correspondents al-Ghoul and al-Sharif. The Israeli military also continues to attack medical facilities, including Nasser Hospital, where a Reuters cameraman is killed. Rescuers attending the scene and media covering the shooting are then hit in a second, follow-up attack, which kills Al Jazeera cameraman Mohammed Salama. These were not just personal tragedies but had all the appearance of systematic targeting of Al Jazeera staff covering t
title: Israel’s systematic targeting of Al Jazeera journalists | The Price of Truth E3 | Al Jazeera World

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
The Israeli military shows no let-up in its attacks in southern Lebanon. 
It's carried out more strikes after issuing forced evacuation warnings to two areas.
Israel says its forces are targeting Hezbollah sites and infrastructure in the towns of Chehour and Deir Kifa. 

It follows an attack on Wednesday that killed at least one person and injured another 11 in the town of al-Tiri.
And at least 13 people died in a strike on a Palestinian refugee camp in the city of Sidon, on Tuesday. 
That's despite last year's ceasefire, which ended 14 months of cross-border conflict with Hezbollah.

Al Jazeera’s Zeina Khodr has more from Beirut, Lebanon.

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
Ukraine says at least 20 people have been killed and dozens injured in missile and drone attacks on the western city of Ternopil.
Russia has stepped up its bombardment of Ukraine's energy infrastructure in recent weeks.
It happened as Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelenskyy visits Turkiye for talks he says are aimed at reinvigorating peace negotiations.

Meanwhile, Poland has announced its closing Russia's last operating consulate in the country, located in the city of Gdansk.
It comes after the Polish government blamed Russia for an attack on a railway line that led to the border with Ukraine.
Moscow has denied involvement in the incident.

Al Jazeera’s Charles Stratford reports and Yulia Shapovalova has the latest from Moscow, Russia. 

Oleksiy Goncharenko is a Ukrainian Member of Parliament with the opposition European Solidarity party. He says the latest Russian attacks underscore Ukraine's need for more military aid.

Subscribe to our channel: http://bit.ly/AJSubscribe
Follow us
title: At least 20 killed in Russian drone, missile attacks across Ukraine

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
Youth-led protests in Nepal last September over corruption and a social media ban were met with police gunfire, leaving 76 people dead.
The violence triggered Prime Minister KP Oli’s resignation and the formation of an interim government under Sushila Karki.
Early elections have been announced for March, alongside a judicial inquiry into the killings and destruction.
Gen Z activists are pushing for accountability, human rights investigations and meaningful youth participation.
Analysts warn of political and constitutional hurdles, particularly from long-entrenched parties.
Yet many Nepalis remain cautiously optimistic that the youth-driven movement can shape a more democratic path forward.
Security officers in Nepal used disproportionate force against the youth-led uprising in September, according to a report by Human Rights Watch.
The rights group has urged the interim government to carry out an independent investigation and prosecute those responsible.

Al Jazeera’s Ramyata Limbu re
title: After deadly protests, Nepal's Gen Z pushes for justice and reform

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
The implementation of reforms by the Palestinian Authority has become a central condition of a UN Security Council resolution on Gaza. 
While the resolution suggests reforms as a prerequisite for statehood and self-determination, the specific demands remain undefined and vary depending on the actors involved. 
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu rejects Palestinian statehood but insists on recognition of Israel as a Jewish state and measures to combat Palestinian factions. 
Meanwhile, key donors, including the European Union, have outlined reform priorities, such as textbook revisions, anti-corruption measures, and elections.
However, Palestinians themselves feel excluded from this narrative, with many expressing dissatisfaction with their leadership and scepticism about the likelihood of elections. 
For Palestinians, the primary concern remains national liberation, sparking questions about whether these reforms align with that goal or merely reinforce a status quo shaped by ext
title: Can the Palestinian Authority balance reforms with liberation goals?

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
Lawmakers in the United States have approved a bill to release government documents related to the late convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, clearing the way for making the files public.
The House of Representatives adopted the measure in a 427-1 vote on Tuesday, and the Senate swiftly agreed to pass it by unanimous consent, skipping a formal roll call, even before the bill was formally transmitted to the chamber.
Once the Senate is back in session on Wednesday, the bill will go to the desk of President Donald Trump, who has said he would sign it into law.

Al Jazeera’s Patty Culhane reports from the Capitol.

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman received an extravagant welcome during his visit to the White House—his first in seven years. 
Despite not being an official head of state, bin Salman was honoured with a state dinner-style reception hosted by US President Donald Trump, complete with red carpet treatment, military flyovers, and high-profile announcements. Trump declared Saudi Arabia a major non-NATO ally, signifying a significant deepening of US-Saudi military cooperation. This designation allows streamlined arms sales and greater defence collaboration between the two nations.
The visit focused heavily on economic and military deals, with bin Salman pledging nearly $1 trillion in US investments, including $142bn for advanced F-35 fighter jets. However, the sale faced opposition from Israel’s lobby, citing laws ensuring Israel’s military superiority in the region. 
Discussions also touched on Saudi Arabia’s ambitions for domestic nuclear energy and Trump’s push for the kingdom to
title: US names Saudi Arabia a major non-NATO ally during Mohammed bin Salman visit

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
At least 13 people have been killed in an Israeli air strike on a Palestinian refugee camp in southern Lebanon, according to the Lebanese Ministry of Public Health.
The drone strike hit a car on Tuesday in the car park of a mosque in the Ein el-Hilweh refugee camp on the outskirts of the coastal city of Sidon, the Lebanese state-run National News Agency reported.
At least four people were wounded in the attack, the ministry said, adding that “ambulances are still transporting more wounded to nearby hospitals.”
Israel said it struck members of the Palestinian armed group Hamas who were operating in a training compound in the refugee camp.
Hamas denied Israel’s claim, calling it a “fabrication” and stressing the group doesn’t have training facilities in Lebanon’s refugee camps.

Al Jazeera’s Felix Nyawara reports.

title: Israeli attack on Palestinian refugee camp in Lebanon kills at least 13

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
Hamas has rejected the UN Security Council passing a US-drafted resolution on Gaza. The council backed Donald Trump's Gaza ceasefire plan, which includes the creation and deployment of an international stabilisation force. The so-called 'Board of Peace' will have sweeping authority over Gaza's governance, its security, and its reconstruction. Palestine's Foreign Minister wants the plan put in place immediately—but Hamas and other armed factions in Gaza say it fails to meet the rights and demands of Palestinians. This resolution has proved controversial in Israel because it refers to the possibility of Palestinian statehood, which Netanyahu has rejected. 

Al Jazeera’s Nour Odeh reports from Ramallah.

title: UN Security Council vote: Hamas rejects US-drafted Gaza 'peace resolution'
